chapter.title: The Projects and Lines tab
chapter.para: Projects and lines are created and managed in the Projects and Lines tab. The right-hand side of the screen shows the details of the selected item, like its name, description and creation date.

mediaobject.caption: Screenshot of the Projects and Lines tab.

tip.para: Try using a context menu instead of the buttons on the toolbar. To do so, right-click on one of the projects or lines which has already been created. Notice that many commands can be found in this context menu. For certain cases this method is even easier and faster then using the toolbar buttons.

section.title: Creating a project
section.para: The steps to create a project are:

procedure.step: Select the tab Projects and Lines;
In the project properties dialog box, fill in the project title (for example, My First Project).
It can also be given a brief description, its author, and an e-mail address;
Click on the OK button to finish.

mediaobject.caption: Title, description, author and e-mail are details that can be edited in the project's properties dialog.

section.para: The project title will appear on the left side of GêBR's main window (see Figure). Information about the project is shown on the right hand side of GêBR's main window. Notice that some of this information comes from what was specified at the project properties dialog, when the project was created. Details such as creation date and modified date are automatically generated by GêBR.

section.title: Creating a line
section.para: To create lines, GêBR must be connected to a maestro (see ). Otherwise, GêBR will not be able to submit flows for running, since this is done through the maestro intervenience.
Lines can be created once there are projects and GêBR is connected to a maestro. To add a new line to a project, follow the steps:

procedure.step: Select the project that will hold the line (see );
A dialog will appear to assist on the remaining steps.

section.para: The assistant will ask the following information:

listitem.para: Basic properties of the line, which are title, description, author, and e-mail address;
The IMPORTIMPORT path: a directory used to easily find files outside the BASE directory.

section.para: When the assistant finishes, the line will be created and shown as being part of the project selected on the beginning of this process. As with projects, the line's settings are exhibited on the right-hand side of GêBR's window.

tip.para: There is no limit to the number of projects and lines in GêBR.

GêBR allows collapsing or expanding the view of the projects. When collapsed, the lines of a project are hidden. When the project is expanded, the lines become visible. To collapse the view, click on the icon on the left side of the project's name. To expand, click on the icon .

section.para: The same settings performed during the creation of a project or line can be altered through the Properties Editing.

To edit project's or line's properties, first select the project or line and then click on the button

section.title: Important folders of a line
section.para: GêBR defines a directories structure to aid in the task of management of the data associated to a set of flows. This structure is defined by a top directory, known as BASEBASE, and few other nested standard directories.
For instance, if the home folder of the user is '/home/john', setting the BASE to '/home/john/GeBR/MyFirstLine/', will have the effect to also define the following directories:
This set of folders can help the user manages the data related to this line (see ).

important.para: Remember that the processing takes place at the Node . So, the directory structure describe above will be created there. In case the node is different from the local machine, where the GêBR interface is running, the user will not see the created directories by browsing the local machine's filesystem.
To be able to browse files in these directory, the remote browseRemote browsing feature must be enabled in the maestroMaestro of the line (see ).

note.para: Although it is not mandatory to adhere to this structure, it is highly recommended to do so.

section.title: Changing the maestro of a line
section.para: GêBR supports only one connected maestroMaestro at time. However, the user may have more than one maestro at the user disposal.

Whenever a maestro is connected, all lines associates to other maestros will be unavailable for edition. The user can however migrate a line from its original maestro to the connected one. To do so, the line must be selected. In the Details panel, an icon in the upper left corner indicates whether the maestro defined for the line is connected or not. In case the original maestro is not the connected one, by clicking over that icon, GêBR will offer two options:

listitem.para: disconnect from the current maestro and connect to the maestro associated to the line; or
dissociate the line from its original maestro and associate it to the connected maestro.

figure.title: Dialog for lines from disconnected maestros

mediaobject.caption: Options available when the user wants to edit/run a line associated to a disconnected maestro.

important.para: When a line is migrated from one maestro to another, all data in the BASEBASE directory and in its children will remain in the nodes of the original maestro.

section.title: Importing a project or a line
section.para: In GêBR the user can import projects or lines that were previously exported (). To do so:

step.para: Select the desired project or line to import in the Choose project/line to open window. Only files with extension prjz, prjx, lnez or lnex will be shown.

section.para: The imported project is added to the list of projects, found on the left of the main window. An imported line joins with the other lines of the project that was selected when the line was imported, if they exist. In both cases the imported item is identified with the suffix Imported.

note.para: In GêBR, lines may only exist inside a project (see this concept in ). Therefore to import a line the user must first select an existing project, or create a new one.

section.title: Exporting a project or a line
section.para: Although GêBR continuously saves all data, sometimes it is desirable to have copies of projects and lines in a file (for example, to share with others or to make backups). To export a project or a line:

step.para: Select the line or project that that will be saved.

A dialog box will appear and, there, tha user can choose the name of the file that will be saved; when you select a directory and type the file name, GêBR determines the extension automatically, .prjx for projects or .lnex for lines.

section.title: Editing comments
section.para: The user can add comments on the reportReportof a projectReportof a line of a project or a line. To do so, follow the steps:

step.para: Left-click on Edit comments, which is located just below Details, in the Project's properties or Line's Properties dialog box.
Fill in some comment in the text editor that is presented. When the comment is edited, save this and close the editor.
In this editor the user can save, print and pre-visualize the comments by pressing one of the icons in the tool bar, or by using the editors menu.

section.title: View the report
section.para: As explained in the above section, the user can edit a report containing additional information about the project or line. To view the report left-click on View Report, found at the bottom of the Details box, which is on the right side of the main window.
After clicking on View Report, a window will appear, where you can:
In the menu Options you can:

step.para: Include the report of the snapshots of flows;
Configure the parameter table pertaining to the flow's programs;
Choose the presentation style of the report, as well as include other styles.

mediaobject.caption: In the View Report window, the user can print or save to a file this report. In the options menu, as is shown above, the user can include: comments, the flow's report, the report of the snapshots of flows, the parameter table and choose from a few pre-defined styles for the report.
